Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New Advances in the Cascade Rearrangement of Furylcarbinols for Complex Molecular Synthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this CAREER Award, the Chemical Synthesis program is supporting the research of Professor Javier Read de Alaniz of the University of California-Santa Barbara. Professor Read de Alaniz will apply new strategies for the synthesis of functionalized five-membered rings. The approach will rely on a domino rearrangement of 2-furylcarbinols, involving a formal 4-pi electrocyclization step, that provides efficient access to functionalized cyclopentenones, themselves important to medicine, biology, and material science. First, an operationally simple synthetic methodology will be developed to construct functionalized five-membered rings, as well as nitrogen heterocycles in a single operation. The intramolecular cascade rearrangement allows for the direct and highly diastereoselective synthesis of azaspirocyclic natural product cores. Second, the cascade rearrangement will be applied to the synthesis of quaternary stereogenic centers. In the final objective, efforts will be directed at achieving an enantioselective cascade rearrangement.

Professor Javier Read de Alaniz will also work with outreach programs at the University of California Santa Barbara to help overcome the lack of minority representation in the sciences. Professor Read de Alaniz will serve as the faculty advisor for the University of California Leadership Excellence through Advanced Degrees (UC LEADS) program. Working with the UC LEADS program Professor Read de Alaniz will participate in and lead a series of professional development workshop for promising underrepresented minority undergraduate students during the summer. The second educational initiative will provide students with the opportunity to interact with postdoctoral research associates and faculty from underrepresented minority/female backgrounds in an organized, yet casual, brown-bag lunch forum. Faculty/post-doctoral research associates will discuss their career pathes along with topics of isolation and language barriers, increasing diversity on the campus, labeling, peer misperceptions, and mentoring.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The majority of industrial chemical processes are based on petrochemical feedstock; limited supplies of crude oil are declining, resulting in an ever-gaping need for the development of routes to chemicals, materials and fuels from renewable sources such as biomass. One such raw material, furfural, is produced from hemicellulose derived from agricultural waste products like bagasse, oat hulls and corncobs. Our group has made significant contributions to sustainable reaction development using furfural, for the synthesis of privileged chemical building blocks. Prior to our contributions, the acid catalyzed rearrangement of furylcarbinols, commonly known as the Piancatelli reaction, was limited to stoichiometric acid catalysts, elevated temperatures (100 °C) and water as the nucleophile. Utilizing an underexplored Lewis acid, dysprosium triflate (Dy(OTf)3), we discovered and demonstrated that the nucleophilic partner can be extended to amines and alcohols. This new approach, termed the aza- and oxa-Piancatelli, provides a powerful method to streamline the synthesis of biologically active and medicinal compounds. The reaction constructs a carbon–carbon bond plus a carbon–heteroatom (nitrogen or oxygen) bond and two stereocenters in a single operation. To highlight the synthetic utility of our methodology, the reaction was used to prepare an hNK1 inhibitor in just six steps from furfural, previously the synthesis required greater than 15 synthetic operations.

To further extend the synthetic utility of the cascade rearrangement, we have also developed the first intramolecular variant that provides rapid access to aza- and oxa-spirocyclic structural motifs, which are embedded in numerous remarkable natural products. The most practical, but also the most difficult and rare approach to construct this challenging spirocyclic framework would be to combine the construction of the tertiary stereocenter and the formation of the spirocyclic ring system in a single operation. This is now possible using our intramolecular aza- and oxa-Piancatelli rearrangements. In summary, by replacing multistep chemical synthesis with novel cascade rearrangements of furfural derivatives we have been able to provide chemists with a new approach to bioactive molecules that does not rely on petrochemical feedstock (Figure 1).   

Broader Impacts: In addition to what we perceive as the useful science that has emerged from this grant, broader impacts include our training of undergraduate researchers, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, as well as extensive outreach contributions to the local and national community. As an underrepresented minority faculty member, I have made a continued effort to place increasing diversity in STEM as a top priority. Highlights of diversity activities during this funding period are outlined below.

  • I served as the faculty mentor for the UC LEADS program four consecutive years.  During the 10-week summer program, I served as the faculty mentor on a panel that helps the students develop their science communication skills. In addition, I helped mentor approximately 20 underrepresented undergraduate minority students that participated in the program.
  • My research group is actively involved in Internships in Nanosystems Science, Engineering and Technology (INSET), Scholarships for Transfer to Engaged and Excel in Mathematics (STEEM), Research Internship in Science and Engineering (RISE), and Graduate Students for Diversity in Science (GSDS) at UCSB. As part of this involvement the PI have given over 30 presentations in past six years about diversity in science at UCSB and mentored greater than 20 undergraduate research students through these programs.
  • Organizer for SACNAS National Conference Symposium Chemistry at the Biology and Materials Interface. The goal of the symposium was to recognize and promote outstanding chemists who belong to underrepresented groups in science. The speakers were all young Assistant Professors (eight in total) who are nationally recognized and were Hispanic. The communication of their work at SACNAS served as a powerful tool to motivate young scientist with similar backgrounds by self-identity and peer-to-peer mentorship.
  • Advisory committee for UCSB’s Opening New Doors to Accelerating Success (ONDAS). This committee enables the university to put into place the necessary tools that students, mainly from underrepresented groups, will need to enter and successfully complete college (2015-present).
  • Advisory board, Bridges to Biomedical Research Careers (BBRC) for UCSB MARC Program (2015-present).
  • Hosted six visiting students from UCLA’s Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) Program (2016).
  • Director of the NSF Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) Bridges to Doctorate (BD) Program (5-year). The NSF BD program will support 12 incoming 2017 PhD students underrepresented in science and engineering with two year of financial support. As director of the BD program, I will provide the general oversight for the 5-year program.
  • Advisory board for diversity – UCSB Graduate Division Dean Carol Genetti (2016-2018).

Through these diversity leadership roles, I have been actively involved in helping to shape the research experience, recruiting and retention of underrepresented minority students at both the undergraduate and graduate student level.
